title: Monday, 4th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Yes, we're back

PM

And pretty much on time as well

11:01 am
PM

And we now know that what everyone really wanted for Xmas was a tinhat

PM

PM

https://twitter.com/XHNews/status/683957083419488257

PM

PM

First day of the new circuit breakers there

11:03 am

So rude not to try them out

PM

Chinese circuit breakers copied from the S&P variety

PM

But what people need to know is that the American ones don't work properly any more

11:04 am

PM

It's here: http://www.sec.gov...ket_volatility.pdf

PM

I havent read properly, but the gist is that the S&P doesn't clock dark pool trades

11:05 am

So the headline index reading was only down 5.2% on that day back in August

PM

PM

Fragile market structure...

undefined

Off 126 points at 6116. Loser-board has a feel of inevitability about it.

PM

11:11 am
BE

Let me share some Macquarie on this.

PM

Sure

BE

Vikas Dwivedi reckons no immediate effect on the oil price, but investors are terrible at seeing the big picture.

11:11 am
BE

And the big picture is really quite bleak.

BE

The event has direct negative implications for any efforts to attain peace in the two
primary Shia/Sunni hotspots, including Syria and Yemen, as well as the ongoing
fight against ISIS. It also comes at a time when the balance of power in the Middle
East, in our view, is shifting away from Saudi Arabia and towards Iran. Saudi’s
shrinking budget revenues, perhaps by its own accord, and increased involvement in
the Yemeni conflict, in which the Washington Post referred to it as Saudi Arabia’s
“Vietnam”, contrasts negatively with Iran’s success in the P5+1 negotiations,
unlocking billions of dollars of revenue and frozen assets, as well as the intervention
by Russia in Syria, shifting the balance in favor of the Iranian-backed Assad regime.

BE

Global crude oil supply/demand dynamics remain unchanged in the near term, and
we expect the market to remain well over supplied in the near term. This weekend’s
events may severely limit the possibility of peace in surrounding countries, but do not
directly threaten crude oil production. We see the following effects on the oil market:
 Short term: neutral – production levels are not impacted;
 Medium term: bearish – decreases possibility of an organized effort by OPEC
to cut production or allow other countries to grow;
 Long term: bullish – implications for longer-term strife and possibility of war.

11:12 am
BE

But ........

BE

Geopolitical risk premium in the oil market remains zero to negative, in spite of nontrivial
events unfolding in the Middle East over the past year. The escalation of
Saudi/Iran or Sunni/Shia tensions continues to be underappreciated by oil investors.
While supply growth continues to overwhelm demand in the near term, the vast
majority of our 2016 supply growth comes from three countries, all located in the
Middle East: Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Iran. Any war between these nations, especially
on Saudi or Iranian soil, represents significant upside to oil prices, even if production
itself is not negatively impacted.

BE

Major wars in the past have been sparked by relatively small catalysts, which in
hindsight, enabled broader, already prevalent antagonistic attitudes to boil over into
major and often times, violent events. The beginning of the Arab Spring, of which the
five year anniversary is today, began following the self immolation of Mohamed
Bouazizi in Tunisia, sparking a wave of revolution across the entire region. Where
tensions already exist, innocuous events may cause seemingly outsized events.

11:13 am
BE

Which is a history lesson I doubt many of us needed.

PM

Five year anniversary of the arab Srping?

BE

Time flies, eh.

11:13 am

11:28 am
undefined
BE

As to actual news ......

BE

We continue to wait for Shire, which was an exclusive-to-all-wires job over the weekend.

11:29 am
BE

Shire ready to pay $46.50-$48 for Baxalta

BE

To create the world's biggest purveyor of rare disease medicines

BE

Shire's already sold off here, of course, to the point that most of the sellside say it's adjusted down to the risks involved.

11:30 am
BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

Investors remain mixed on whether this is the right step forward for SHP but nevertheless a deal is still on the table. StreetAccount headlines this morning state that Shire is in advanced talks to acquire Baxalta for $46.50-48.50 per share, which would equate to a total deal value of $32bn using a mix of cash and stock. We recently published a scenario analysis (using Shire + recently acquired Dyax as the baseline) and estimated that at the share prices as of Dec 16 a $50/BXLT share deal with 25% cash/75% equity could generate a range of -4% to 5% of 2020 accretion using a synergy range of $400 per annum (10% of BXLT OPEX) to $1300m per annum (30% of BXLT OPEX). Stepping up the cash component from 25% to 35%, all else equal, led to 2020 accretion of 4-14%.
We update this analysis for illustrative purposes today for the current share prices (as of last close) and use the bid prices of $46.50 and $48.50/BXLT share in this morning's StreetAccount article. At $46.50/BXLT share, our analysis suggests a 25% cash/75% equity bid could generate 2020 EPS accretion of 1-11% assuming a synergy range of 10%-30% of BXLT’s OPEX. At $48.50/BXLT share, we find that a 25% cash/75% equity bid could generate 2020 EPS accretion of 0-9% assuming a synergy range of 10%-30% of BXLT’s OPEX. Given the cash-generative nature of haemophilia, we further estimate that a bid at or over $48.50/share would position Shire as net cash by 2019/20 and levered by only 2.6x net debt/EBITDA in the near term - in our view hardly a stretched multiple.

BE

And Suntrust.

11:31 am
BE

BXLT deal to be finalized 1st week in Jan. targeting mid-16 close. NEWCO model assumes deal is neutral to EPS in ’16 & accretive thereafter achieving a (+) ROIC. Our revised base case assumes 60%/40% stock/cash, with accretion in 2017 assuming conservative sales/opex synergies. We estimate that each 1%/$100M in sales/opex synergies yields $0.21/$0.29 of incremental accretion. We lowered ’16-’18 EPS on the SHPG+DYAX (DYAX, $37.62,NR) NEWCO/ lifitegrast launch costs, but raised out yr EPS. Our ’17E-‘21E NEWCO EPS CAGR is 19% vs. 15% for standalone. Maintain BUY/$298PT on ~18x our NEWCO ‘17 EPS.

BE

We expect SHPG to revise the deal terms for Baxalta (BXLT, $39.03, Not Rated) after five months of friendly due diligence with BXLT. We expect the transaction to value BXLT shares at $47.25 (mid-point of the $46.50-$48 range reported in several media sources), representing a 43% premium to BXLT’s August 3, 2015 (the day before the SHPG merger proposal was reported) closing price, with the deal assumed to close by mid-2016. Levels of accretion in our NEWCO model vary depending on the structure of the deal (our base case scenario is 60% stock, 40% cash). We expect the deal to be structured in a manner that is tax efficient for BXLT shareholders, given the tax free BXLT spin-off from Baxter International (BAX, $38.15, not rated) in June 2015. Regardless of structure, we expect the deal to be accretive to earnings in 2017. Our ROIC analysis assumes the deal generates a positive ROI clearing SHPG’s WACC by 2021.

BE

SHPG’s shares have sold off ~27% since August (to ~$196 from $268). Under our base case scenario, our NEWCO model assumes sales ‘17E-‘21E sales synergies of 0.5%, 1%, 5%, 6%, & 7%, yielding 17E-21E sales CAGR of 10%. We assume SHPG realizes up to 40% operating synergies, and a projected tax rate of 16.5% in out years. We also model a $6B share repurchase in 2H16 through 1H18, resulting in a modest dilution (-$0.05) on EPS in 16E, but 17E/18E/19E/20E/21E EPS accretion of 10% ($1.59), 14% ($2.54), 14% ($3.34), 21% ($5.48), & 27% ($7.13). The estimated 17E-21E EPS CAGR is 19% vs. 15% for SHPG standalone. We project the NEWCO to offer a ROIC of 11.1% by 2023E, materially above SHPG’s WACC of ~9.2%.

11:31 am
BE

We think BXLT makes strategic sense for SHPG as BXLT’s pipeline complements SHPG’s Rare Diseases (RD) platform. Acquiring BXLT adds several multi-billion franchises in hematology, immunology & oncology, which are high value global markets with significant barriers to entry. The NEWCO expands SHPG’s reach geographically in Rare Diseases, provides meaningful synergies, while lessening dependence on its Neuroscience small molecule franchise that includes Vyvanse, Intuniv & Adderall XR. Our NEWCO model assumes SHPG’s Neuroscience franchise declines to 16% of total sales from 29% for the stand-alone SHPG in 2022 just prior to the Vyvanse loss of exclusivity. Our NEWCO assumes the combined company generates greater than $20B in geographically diverse sales by 2020E (we model $21B after adding the Dyax Corp (DYAX, $37.62, not rated) acquisition, discussed in detail below), more than double SHPG’s existing $10B by ‘20E plan for the stand-alone company, with ~50% of sales from ex-US markets. Rare Diseases (RD) accounted for ~40% of SHPG’s 2014 revenue, while Neuroscience accounted for 37%. The NEWCO is expected to generate ~65% of its 2020E sales from RD across greater than 50 products (including 30 new product launches generating greater than $5B in pipeline sales by 2020E), positioning the NEWCO as the largest RD company targeting greater than 100 markets globally.

BE

So anyway ......

BE

...Just out of curiosity, I was trying to find out some Baxalta drug dose pricing this morning

11:32 am
BE

And it's really difficult.

PM

oh yeah?

BE

Best I could find was that Advate, the legacy haemophilia treatment, costs a patient (via their insurer or whatever) about $600k a year.

11:33 am
PM

600k a year??????

BE

The replacement to Advate is going to be priced at a premium to that.

BE

In fact, it was due to be priced in the fourth quarter on release. But I can't find any announcement or report giving details.

11:34 am
BE

Perhaps one of the ROTR can help me out here.

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

PM

Doesnt feel like a growth market

11:35 am
BE

That's one risk, I guess. I'd also note the political risk of a change in the system whereby rare diseases are charged at a scarcity premium.

BE

Though since I'm on it ... Had an argument with a doctor about this over the holidays.

BE

(Which is the kind of thing I do on holiday.)

11:36 am
BE

Basically, the argument was that US patients are ripped off massively for their drugs.

BE

But the counter-argument is that UK patients are undercharged massively.

BE

So, effectively, one system is subsidising the other.

11:37 am
PM

Eh?

BE

Well, we have NICE, the NHS body that controls drug prices.

BE

And unless your drug gets UK approval and NICE backing, it'll have a tougher time with other regulators.

11:38 am
PM

It's a flimsy argument -- idea that $20k toe rot treatments do good for British sickies

BE

It's an argument, flimsy or otherwise. It says that in effect, the UK is helping regulate the world drug industry and getting cheap drugs in return.

BE

Anyway, I note it. And now we can move on.

11:39 am
PM

ok

BE

(@Roddy: Quality-adjusted life years is the metric NICE tends to use. It's really quite fascinating, if you're a dork.)

11:54 am
BE

BE

(I had a small argument with the Grainger PR because I tried to avoid the phrase "reversionary leases" in copy)

11:54 am
BE

Anyway, this is not that. But it's incrementally positive.

BE

According to JP Morgan, which says .....

BE

The
transaction has four main benefits in our view: 1) The sale is a clear sign of
new CEO Helen Gordon's intention to streamline the business, focusing on the
residential rental sector 2). The sale lowers debt costs as the debt transferred
has a cost of 6.9% vs the group average 4.6%. 3) reinvestment could more
than double recurring net profit on the £350m of capital proceeds to £13.6m.
4) LTV post sale will fall to less than 40% from 45.5% at September 2015.

11:55 am
BE

Grainger’s wide range of residential related businesses is not fully
valued by the market, and the streamlining of the business model along
with a greater focus on residential rental income will be a positive for the
equity story, in our view. CEO Helen Gordon said “this is an important
transaction for Grainger. It accelerates the transition to a business focused
on the residential rented sector and will simplify the Group. It will
materially reduce our financial and operational costs, including costs
associated with running a FCA regulated business, and will significantly
strengthen our balance sheet and capacity for investment.”
 Proceeds to be reinvested in residential rental business (PRS): We
assume the £350m proceeds are reinvested in PRS at a gross yield of 7.0%,
achievable outside of SE England markets, using a 50% debt capital
structure and incremental debt cost of LIBOR +170 bps (the refinancing rate
of the syndicate debt refinancing in FY15). This would imply net income at
a 30% cost margin of 4.9% or £17.15m, and debt costs of £3.9m for
recurring rental based Net Profit of £13.6m vs the £6.1m recurring income
from the retirement solutions business. The impact of reinvestment will not
be fully felt until the FY17 period. This would also represent a 7.8% ROE
on the £175m, clearly accretive and a step in the right direction.

BE

And Peel Hunt.

BE

The equity release division is being sold for £325m which
equates to c12% of Grainger’s entire portfolio. The transaction
includes £150m of attached debt and the deal will reduce
leverage and the cost of debt. The price is marginally below the
Sep ‘15 market value and after mark-to-market debt and tax
adjustments, the sale will lead to an £18m or c1% reduction in
Gross NAV. The new CEO is holding a strategy day on 28
January and today’s deal likely gives an indication of what
to expect.

BE

According to data provided by the NBS, there were approximately 14 million homes for sale or under construction as of late 2015, a significant proportion of which wasn’t in top markets like Beijing and Shanghai. What this could mean for the market is that in order to clear inventory, price cuts may be the only way to do so, which will need to be offset by firmer prices in top markets to protect margins. If such a scenario plays out, the separation between major cities and rural areas in China will only strengthen, exacerbating existing imbalances while creating a hurdle for long-term goals of urbanization.
